Other Answers (10) Show: All Answers Oldest to Newest Newest to Oldest Rated Highest to Lowest by Jakarta Worker Member since: 07 April 2006 Total points: 14,523 (Level 6) Add Contact Block It might be easier if they go through the drive-thru. And have them come either later in the evening (like an hour before closing) when your manager is in the back doing paperwork or during a busy rush period. They can go back through the drive thru and say you forgot to give them something from their order. During the rush period you can bag up extra stuff for them without anyone noticing. But tell them not to do it too often because getting fired for trying to hook your friends up is embarassing. 3 years ago Report Abuse 27% 4 Votes by -T- Member since: 19 September 2006 Total points: 1,895 (Level 3) Add Contact Block I used to do this when I worked at McD's in the early 90's. I often times worked drive-thru and friends of mine would come through occasionally. If I was working as a presenter (DT orders) or window (cashier), I'd simply add a few extra sandwiches and fries to the bag. I told my friends I could get them extra food, but not totally free-they'd have to order something so it didn't seem suspicious. If it was busy, the other workers never noticed or cared; they're not really paying attention to what you're doing unless it's causing a problem. 3 years ago Report Abuse 27% 4 Votes by niceguyl... It just takes one slip up and you get your pink slip. 3 years ago Report Abuse 0% 0 Votes 3 people rated this as good by Tonto Member since: 12 October 2008 Total points: 1,854 (Level 3) Add Contact Block These people really think you are a push over and a dweeb to ask you to give them food.
